docs.lead_paragraph: A drug commonly used to control seizures reduced the discomfort and sleep disruption of patients with restless legs syndrome, according to a small study released yesterday. The study, published in the journal Neurology, said treatment with the drug, gabapentin, could mean greater relief with fewer side effects than the standard medications, variants of dopamine.
docs.abstract: Study published in journal Neurology contends gabapentin, drug used to control seizures, may bring substantial relief to those suffering from restless leg syndrome; syndrome is thought to effect 5 to 10 percent of population; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: A drug commonly used to control seizures reduced the discomfort and sleep disruption of patients with restless legs syndrome, according to a small study released yesterday.     The study, published in the journal Neurology, said treatment with the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Bruce Hayse introduced himself to the audience of doctors at a course in wilderness medicine as ''the token pro-hazard speaker.'' The hazards of wilderness travel, he said, ''force you into coming to terms with what's really important in life,'' learning who you are and how to make life-and-death decisions. ''You're not going to learn that sort of thing playing golf,'' he said.

headline.main: Avoid Risks of Wilderness Travels? Not on Your Life

docs.abstract: Dr Bruce Hayse, who recently taught course in wilderness medicine at American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene conference in Denver, contends contracting illness while traveling can teach you about yourself and lead you to have more compassion for others; asserts that hazards of wilderness travel can force you to make life-and-death decisions and to discover what is really important in life; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study from the Isle of Wight suggests that the number of children with peanut allergies is increasing. The study, published last week in The Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology, tested two groups of children, one born in 1989 and the other from 1994 to 1996, for sensitivity to peanuts.
docs.abstract: Isle of Wight study published in Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology, reports increase in peanut allergies; lead researcher Dr Syed Hasan Arshad suggests that allergies can be transmitted to infants by nursing mothers; photo (S)
docs.snippet: A new study from the Isle of Wight suggests that the number of children with peanut allergies is increasing.    The study, published last week in The Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology, tested two groups of children, one born in 1989 and the...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the mountains, climbers and hikers risk altitude illness and frostbite. In the valleys, parasites wriggle in the water. In the African jungle, mosquitoes bring malaria and tse tse flies, sleeping sickness. The sea is full of venom. And in the Amazon, there is the infamous urethra fish, or candiru, a creature that occasionally swims up a human urethra, flares its gill covers in apparent panic at its mistake and gets stuck -- the very definition of adding insult to injury.
docs.abstract: Article outlines topics discussed at Denver meeting of American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene's course for physicians on wilderness medicine; some of hazards in wilderness areas noted; cartoons (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Botox injections can smooth out a patient's forehead but may also limit the mobility of the eyebrows, according to a new study. Thousands of Americans have flocked to have wrinkles temporarily removed through injections of botulinum A exotoxin (as Botox is formally known), which paralyzes the facial muscles that cause the skin to crease. But the paralysis has led to complaints that Botox is causing an outbreak of smooth but bland faces, as frozen muscles limit the delicate muscular movements that signal emotions.
docs.abstract: Indiana University Medical Center's Dr Mimi S Kokoska report, published in Archives of Facial Plastic Surgery, finds that patients using botox to erase forehead wrinkles experience diminished eyebrow movement; botox sales are estimated to total around $430 million this year; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Football coaches, Enron executives and political spin doctors might all profit from a professional consultation with Dr. Barry Schlenker. Dr. Schlenker, a professor of psychology at the University of Florida, is an expert on people's attempts to evade or diminish their responsibility for the irresponsible, thoughtless, inadequate, stupid or hurtful things they do -- in other words, on the art of making excuses.
docs.abstract: Dr Barry Schlenker, psychology professor at University of Florida, and colleagues Drs Beth Pontari and Andrew Christopher publish report in Journal of Social and Clinical Psychology that warns of pitfalls associated with blaming others for our own mistakes; holds that study contends that long-term avoidance of responsibility for errors can lead to false sense of reality and eventually cause greater problems; finds that society views excuse makers as weak and even dishonest, even if excuse is reasonable (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The holiday season promises to bring a serious threat to thousands of of sleep-deprived Americans -- a motor vehicle accident that could injure or kill the driver, passengers, pedestrians or people in other vehicles. A recent poll by the National Sleep Foundation revealed that in the past year, half of Americans said they had driven drowsy at least once, and one in five drivers admitted to falling asleep at the wheel.

headline.main: Dark Side of Holidays: Sleep-Deprived Drivers

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column offers advice on hazards of sleep-deprived driving and gives ways for drivers to self-diagnose and remedy sleepiness at wheel; holds that 20% of all road accidents are sleep related as society is becoming more and more sleep deficient; solutions to help drivers stay alert while driving include having company, getting plenty of sleep night before, taking lots of breaks and best of all, stopping to nap; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: The holiday season promises to bring a serious threat to thousands of of sleep-deprived Americans -- a motor vehicle accident that could injure or kill the driver, passengers, pedestrians or people in other vehicles.    A recent poll by the National...

docs.lead_paragraph: A chest belt with a battery-operated pump appears to do a better job of keeping blood flowing than standard CPR, according to a study presented last week at a conference of the American Heart Association. Dr. Henry R. Halperin, a cardiologist from the Johns Hopkins Medical Institutions, presented data showing that the belts, when combined with shots of epinephrine, were able to restore nearly normal blood flow to the hearts and brains of pigs that had been put into cardiac arrest. By contrast, he said, a device that mimics standard CPR restored 20 to 25 percent of circulation.

headline.main: A Wide Belt, to Save the Heart

docs.abstract: Cardiologist Dr Henry R Halperin presents encouraging data on effectiveness of new chest belt that mimics CPR at American Heart Association conference; cites several ways belt, developed by company Revivant, may work better than CPR in saving patient suffering cardiac arrest (S)
docs.snippet: A chest belt with a battery-operated pump appears to do a better job of keeping blood flowing than standard CPR, according to a study presented last week at a conference of the American Heart Association.     Dr. Henry R. Halperin, a cardiologist...

docs.lead_paragraph: Important drugs, devices, procedures and operations to treat heart disease are widely available, and American specialty groups have issued guidelines that generally agree on their best use. So, ideally, heart patients should receive the same optimal therapy wherever they are treated. In reality, they do not. Findings from a small number of studies reported at a meeting of the American Heart Association here last week highlighted a gap between what guidelines call for in preventing and treating particular heart conditions and what doctors actually prescribe for them. Differences in how often doctors apply guidelines for heart disease, which is the nation's leading cause of death, have exposed serious flaws in health care.

headline.main: 'Standard' Heart Treatment Is Hit and Miss

docs.abstract: Researchers, presenting findings at American Heart Association meeting in Chicago, discuss gap in use by physicians of guidelines for heart disease; for number of reasons, notably differences in patients themselves, various doctors and hospitals do not follow guidelines; statistics are given that show measured improvement in survival when standards are followed and speakers Dr Sidney C Smith Jr and Dr Eric D Peterson encourage use of available information and proceedures to save lives; photo (M)
